Robin Saam [a][,][b], [∗], Ludwig Hagen Letzig a, Jens Grabow a, Ralf Benger b,c, Ines Hauer b,c a _Volkswagen_ _AG, Gifhorner_ _Straße_ _180, Brunswick, 38112, Lower_ _Saxony, Germany_
b _Clausthal_ _University_ _of_ _Technology,_ _Institute_ _of_ _Electrical_ _Power_ _Engineering_ _and_ _Energy_ _Systems, Leibnizstraße_ _28, Clausthal-Zellerfeld, 38678, Lower_
_Saxony, Germany_
c _Clausthal_ _University_ _of_ _Technology,_ _Research_ _Center_ _Energy_ _Storage_ _Technologies, Am_ _Stollen_ _19A, Goslar, 38640, Lower_ _Saxony, Germany_ H I G H L I G H T S - Regional usage differences significantly
impact battery state of health loss. - Predict vehicle battery age and mileage
at regulatory compliance boundaries. - Integrated data-driven framework links
battery aging to real-world usage patterns. - Clustering identifies vehicle groups with
distinct battery degradation behaviors. A R T I C L E I N F O _Keywords:_
Lithium-ion batteries
Service life
Data analytics
Machine learning
Fleet data
Electric vehicle G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T A B S T R A C T _Battery_ _Electric_ _Vehicle_ s (BEVs) face stringent regulatory requirements for battery durability, with Euro 7 and
_Advanced_ _Clean_ _Cars_ _II_ (ACCII) regulations mandating _State_ _of_ _Health_ (SoH) thresholds of 70 % after 8 years or
160 _,_ 000 km and 10 years or 240 _,_ 000 km, respectively. Current testing protocols rely on homogeneous profiles
that inadequately represent real-world usage variability, creating recall and over-engineering risks. This paper
addresses this gap by proposing a data-driven framework linking usage behavior patterns with battery aging
dynamics to identify representative test profiles. The framework consists of three integrated steps: (1) predicting battery age and usage at regulatory
boundaries through mathematical formulation, (2) estimating SoH using machine learning models including
ensemble methods and statistical approaches, and (3) clustering vehicles into groups with homogeneous aging
behavior. Unlike existing approaches, it accounts for real-world heterogeneity across diverse usage patterns
without assuming predefined load profiles.
chunks.section_name: Battery aging and behavioral pattern identification: A fleet analytics framework for regulatory compliance testing

chunks.text:
The framework consists of three integrated steps: (1) predicting battery age and usage at regulatory
boundaries through mathematical formulation, (2) estimating SoH using machine learning models including
ensemble methods and statistical approaches, and (3) clustering vehicles into groups with homogeneous aging
behavior. Unlike existing approaches, it accounts for real-world heterogeneity across diverse usage patterns
without assuming predefined load profiles. Validation used a large-scale Volkswagen AG fleet of roughly 850,000 vehicles across five countries (China,
Germany, Italy, Norway, United States). Analysis across regions demonstrates how usage behavior diversity
impacts battery aging, validating the need for behavioral pattern-aware methodologies. The framework was ∗ Corresponding author at: Volkswagen AG, Gifhorner Straße 180, Brunswick, 38112, Lower Saxony, Germany. _E-mail_ _address:_ [robin.saam@volkswagen.de](mailto:robin.saam@volkswagen.de) (R. Saam). [https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyai.2025.100669](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.egyai.2025.100669)

chunks.text:
_R._ _Saam_ _et_ _al._ **1.** **Introduction** _Energy_ _and_ _AI_ _24_ _(2026)_ _100669_ complemented by _Center_ _for_ _Advanced_ _Life_ _Cycle_ _Engineering_ (CALCE) battery cycling validation (192 cells, 24
test groups), achieving Homogeneity 0.9157 and Completeness 0.9509. The modular design enables future enhancements including multi-view clustering and advanced SoH
prediction models. This framework provides manufacturers a systematic approach to regulatory compliance
while reducing unnecessary testing and mitigating over-engineering risk. Batteries have become indispensable in modern life, as highlighted
by Iser and Schadwinkel [1]. They power everyday handheld devices
such as smartphones, enable the integration of renewable energy into
power grids [2], and serve as the core energy source for BEVs [3]. Recent studies by Fichtner et al. [3] and Passerini et al. [4] emphasize that
future battery development must address multiple challenges, including
improvements in ‘‘ _energy_ _density[...][,_ _R.S.]_ _fast_ _charging_ _[capabilities,_
_R.S.][...]_ _sustainability_ _of_ _resources,_ _the_ _recyclability_ _of_ _components,_ _cycle-_
_and_ _calendar_ _lifetime_ _of_ _the_ _system,_ _safety_ _and_ _costs_ ’’ [3, p. 4]. These requirements are particularly critical for automotive applications, where
diverse usage patterns and environmental conditions influence battery
performance. The global demand for batteries is projected to rise significantly
in terms of overall battery capacity, driven by the electrification of
transport and renewable integration. According to Passerini et al. [4]
the annual growth rate for batteries since 2010 is 30 % with smaller
annual growth rates to be estimated by 2030 onward. Fichtner et al. [3] highlight the role of automotive applications and upcoming battery
chemistries where a shift to post lihtium-ion batteries is expected.
Additionally, the International Energy Agency forecasts an ongoing
increase in BEVs in the upcoming years [5]. This growing diversity
in battery chemistries combined with an increase in demand complicates product comparison for consumers and motivates legislators to
establish harmonized standards.

[3] highlight the role of automotive applications and upcoming battery
chemistries where a shift to post lihtium-ion batteries is expected.
Additionally, the International Energy Agency forecasts an ongoing
increase in BEVs in the upcoming years [5]. This growing diversity
in battery chemistries combined with an increase in demand complicates product comparison for consumers and motivates legislators to
establish harmonized standards. In the automotive sector, two major regulatory frameworks are
shaping battery lifetime requirements: the Euro 7 regulation by the European Commission [6] in the European Union and the ACCII regulation by the _California_ _Air_ _Resources_ _Board_ (CARB) [7] in the United
States. Both aim to ensure durability and reliability of traction batteries
in BEVs, setting minimum thresholds for the remaining service life,
commonly expressed as SoH. Inside this paper, the capacity-based
definition of SoH will be used, as recommended by the United Nations [8], to ensure consistency with international standards and regulatory frameworks. Furthermore, the capacity-based SoH will simply
be referred to as SoH throughout this paper. The ACCII regulation will apply from model year 2026, as outlined
in the official CARB documentation [7], with detailed compliance
requirements specified in the technical guidelines [9]. Despite similar
minimum SoH requirements (70 %), the regulations differ in their durability targets: Euro 7 mandates compliance after 8 years or 160 _,_ 000 km,
whereas ACCII requires 10 years or 240 _,_ 000 km. These thresholds will
be further referred to as _regulatory_ _boundaries_ . Furthermore, by 2030,
ACCII will tighten its requirement to 80 % SoH. Non-compliance can
trigger recalls if more than 10 % of a fleet fails to meet these limits,
as stated in CARB’s enforcement policy [10] and confirmed by international regulatory guidelines [8]. Consequently, SoH requirements are
closely linked to the _End_ _of_ _Warranty_ (EoW) criteria defined by manufacturers (e.g., Volkswagen AG [11] or Tesla, Inc. [12]), which often
align with regulatory thresholds. For instance, Volkswagen specifies an
EoW capacity of 70 % [11]. To the best of current knowledge, existing
regulations do not provide exemptions for specific usage patterns, such
as frequent fast charging. However, the SoH is influenced by both the age of the battery and its
usage patterns, which are directly linked to vehicle operation, making
compliance under all circumstances challenging for manufacturers. Previous studies have examined the relationship between usage and
battery aging from different perspectives. Broussely et al. [13] provided

Previous studies have examined the relationship between usage and
battery aging from different perspectives. Broussely et al. [13] provided foundational insights into electrochemical degradation mechanisms,
while Keil et al. [14] focused on aging differences caused by temperature and cell chemistry. In contrast, Vermeer et al. [15] offered a
comprehensive review of how usage parameters impact battery aging
and interact with each other. More recently, von Bülow [16] analyzed
the variability of aging in real-world BEV fleet conditions over full
equivalent cycles. Many of these insights, however, were obtained
under controlled laboratory conditions. To mitigate the risk of recalls despite the large variety of influencing factors, batteries must undergo rigorous testing. Current testing
protocols typically rely on homogeneous profiles that fail to represent
real-world variability [17]. For example, Schreiber et al. [18] expanded
on these findings by detailing aging mechanisms occurring under standardized profiles, while Geslin et al. [19] emphasized that such profiles
hinder accurate lifetime predictions. Furthermore, Saam et al. [20]
demonstrated that real-world usage profiles differ substantially across
user percentiles, highlighting the need for more representative testing
approaches. Nazari et al. [21] provided an overview of conducted research using
different clustering algorithms for across use cases to separate BEVs in
groups. Forte et al. [22] additional provides an overview of real-world
charging datasets. Nevertheless, to the best of current knowledge, no
existing methodology aims to reduce the overall variability of usage
behaviors and prioritize testing on key groups based on predictions at
regulatory boundaries. To address this gap, a workflow is introduced
that divides usage behaviors into subgroups according to their influence
on battery aging. This enables engineers to select representative behaviors from relevant user groups to ensure compliance with automotive
regulations. Depending on the application, these groups may represent
either critical usage patterns or the majority of typical users. To the best
of current knowledge, no comparable regulations have been established
for other battery applications [23], although implicit requirements
persist through existing quality standards. Consequently, the proposed
workflow can be meaningfully applied to other battery domains. In general, the workflow consists of three main steps:

In general, the workflow consists of three main steps: This study introduces a data-driven framework that predicts intersections with regulatory boundaries without relying on predefined
historical load profiles. It compares multiple SoH estimation methods,
such as RFR and nonlinear optimization, for diverse usage scenarios. KMeans clustering then categorizes vehicles into distinct aging groups,
with clustering performance rigorously evaluated. The goal is not to
claim superiority of each step but to demonstrate how integrating these
components extracts actionable insights and derives representative test
parameters. While based on established techniques, the novelty lies in
systematically integrating regulatory boundary prediction, SoH estimation, and behavioral clustering into a modular, scalable pipeline. This
unified workflow enables continuous data flow, cross-validation, and
interpretability, directly connecting operational behaviors with battery
aging and regulatory compliance. Integration enhances robustness and
provides flexibility to adapt to evolving data and regulatory demands,
distinguishing this method from standalone approaches. This work
focuses on the methodological integration of established techniques
rather than providing a fully implemented software framework. 1. Predicting _battery_ _age_ _𝑡_ and _cumulative_ _usage_ _𝑢_ (e.g., mileage or cycles) at the intersection with regulatory boundaries.
2. Estimating SoH at the intersection point.
3. Clustering this information to identify representative user groups with similar aging behavior. 2

_R._ _Saam_ _et_ _al._ Regarding the structure of the paper, Section 2 provides an overview
of relevant literature, covering approaches for predicting intersections
with regulatory boundaries, clustering of BEV usage data, and SoH
estimation methods. Section 3 introduces the fleet dataset on which the
proposed framework was developed and tested, and illustrates usage
differences across five countries: China, Germany, Italy, Norway, and
the United States. Additionally, the openly available battery dataset
provided by CALCE [24] is presented. This dataset is used as a complementary source for steps where fleet data cannot be disclosed due
to confidentiality constraints. It was selected for its variety of test
cases [24], which resemble diverse real-world usage behaviors, and
its strong representation in the scientific community, as highlighted in
literature reviews by Hasib et al. [25], dos Reis et al. [26], and Tan
et al. [27]. Section 4 elaborates on how usage behavioral patterns impact aging,
specifically showcasing SoH-loss differences across the five countries
introduced in Section 3. Section 5 details the proposed framework,
including the estimation of intersections with regulatory boundaries,
calculation of SoH at these boundaries, and identification of representative usage groups. Each step of the framework is illustrated and
validated using both the fleet dataset and the CALCE dataset. Section 6 discusses current limitations and emphasizes the modular design of the framework, which allows individual steps to be replaced
by improved methods without altering the overall structure. Finally,
Section 7 provides a summary and conclusion. **2.** **Related** **work** This section reviews existing research relevant to the proposed
framework. It is organized into three areas: approaches for predicting
battery age and cumulative usage at regulatory boundaries, clustering
techniques applied to BEV usage data, and methods for estimating
battery SoH. _2.1._ _Predicting_ _intersection_ _with_ _regulatory_ _boundaries_

_2.1._ _Predicting_ _intersection_ _with_ _regulatory_ _boundaries_ Predicting battery age _𝑡_ and cumulative usage _𝑢_ at regulatory boundaries has been addressed through various statistical and machine learning approaches. Geisser [28] introduced baseline statistical methods for
forecasting problems with repeated observations, which can be adapted
to vehicle lifetime prediction. These approaches typically assume a
common mechanism underlying user behavior, such as an average daily
mileage with deviations for holidays or day-dependent circumstances.
While such assumptions simplify modeling, they may not fully capture
real-world variability. Similarly, linear regression offers an alternative
for estimating the intersection point. However, such models primarily
rely on historical averages and long-term trends, making them insensitive to changes in driving behavior. For example, if the owner begins
driving substantially more kilometers per day than before, the regression model will fail to adequately adjust to this shift, as it interprets
recent deviations as random noise rather than a structural change in
usage patterns. _2.2._ _Clustering_ _BEV_ _usage_ _behavioral_ _data_ Clustering is a widely used technique for grouping entities based
on similarity [29]. Algorithms can be categorized into partitioning,
hierarchical, density-based, and other types, as discussed in the comprehensive survey by Xu and Tian [30], which lists a variety of clustering
algorithms and their use cases. A more recent review by Yin et al. [31] provides a concise overview of different clustering topics and
confirms these categorizations. Among these, K-Means [32] and Fuzzy
C-Means [33], as originally proposed in their respective works, are
widely recognized clustering methods and are frequently applied in
electric vehicle contexts. _Energy_ _and_ _AI_ _24_ _(2026)_ _100669_ **Charging** **Behavior** **and** **Infrastructure** **Planning:** Clustering has
been widely applied to analyze charging patterns and optimize infrastructure planning. For instance, Xiong et al. [34] combined clustering
with machine learning to predict day-ahead parking and charging of
BEVs, enabling improved load forecasting. Similarly, Märtz et al. [35]
identified user groups with similar charging behavior using K-Means,
while Yang et al. [36] introduced a Fuzzy C-Means approach to handle
uncertainty in charging patterns. Forte et al. [37] demonstrated how
clustering charging data can optimize planning for charge point operators and energy distribution system operators. Infrastructure-related
studies include Bui et al. [38], who applied clustering to reduce energy
imports during high-price periods via vehicle-to-vehicle load balancing,
and Abdullahi et al. [39], who used clustering to determine optimal
locations for new charging stations.

**Driving** **Profiles** **and** **Behavioral** **Analysis:** Driving profile clustering has also been explored: Fotouhi and Montazeri-Gh [40] derived
micro-trip-based test profiles for cars, and Yuhui et al. [41] extended
this approach to buses. Balaram et al. [42] focused on clustering
profiles to identify similarities in stay-at-home time, _Depth_ _of_ _Discharge_
(DoD), and daily mileage. **Battery** **State** **and** **Second-Life** **Applications:** Clustering plays a
critical role in battery state estimation and second-life applications. Li
et al. [43] grouped cells into homogeneous modules based on performance, Ran et al. [44] clustered batteries for second-life applications, Zhang et al. [45] used _Electrochemical_ _Impedance_ _Spectroscopy_
(EIS) features to classify performance, and Wang et al. [46] applied
clustering to detect abnormal degradation for safe operation. Recent
work has extended clustering to data enrichment and second-life applications. For example, Zafar et al. [47] identified similar groups across
two BEV charging datasets, one data-rich and one data-sparse, and then
applied transfer learning to improve forecasting accuracy for the sparse
dataset. Likewise, Liu et al. [48] proposed a framework for grouping batteries for second-life applications by using EIS and _Incremental_
_Capacity_ _Analysis_ (ICA) to form homogeneous clusters. Comprehensive
reviews of clustering algorithms and their applications in EV contexts
are provided by Nazari et al. [21] and Forte et al. [22]. **Validation** **of** **Clustering** **Results:** Evaluating clustering performance is essential to ensure meaningful groupings. Two main validation approaches are commonly distinguished: _internal_ _validation_ and
_external_ _validation_ [49]. Internal validation relies on metrics derived
from the clustering inputs, such as cohesion and separation, whereas
external validation compares clustering results against independent
ground truth labels. In practice, ground truth labels are often unavailable in large-scale fleet datasets, which limits the applicability of
external validation and makes internal validation the default choice in
many studies. Liu et al. [50] provides an overview of eleven internal
validation metrics, including the Calinski-Harabasz index, Silhouette
index, and Davies–Bouldin index, while Yin et al. [31] summarizes
commonly used external validation metrics. It should be noted that
the terms _index_ and _score_ are sometimes used interchangeably in the
literature. _2.3._ _State_ _of_ _health_ _estimation_ _approaches_

_2.3._ _State_ _of_ _health_ _estimation_ _approaches_ Battery SoH estimation is critical for predicting performance and
lifetime. Early approaches relied on physics-based models and statistical methods. For example, Li et al. [51] proposed a framework capable
of predicting capacity and internal resistance trajectories from early-life
data, while O’Kane et al. [52] demonstrated the use of _Python_ _Battery_
_Mathematical_ _Modelling_ (PyBaMM) for degradation modeling. **Machine** **Learning** **and** **Deep** **Learning** **Models:** Recent reviews [53] summarize common machine learning approaches such as linear
regression, support vector regression, _Multilayer_ _Perceptron_ s (MLPs),
and recurrent architectures like _Long_ _Short_ _Term_ _Memory_ (LSTM). The
concept of _Recurrent_ _Neural_ _Network_ s (RNNs) was first introduced
by Rumelhart et al. [54], forming the basis for sequence modeling. 3

_R._ _Saam_ _et_ _al._ Building on this, Hochreiter and Schmidhuber [55] proposed the LSTM
architecture to address the vanishing gradient problem inherent in
traditional RNNs. Later, Cho et al. [56] introduced _Gated_ _Recurrent_ _Unit_
(GRU) as a simplified alternative to LSTMs, reducing computational
complexity while maintaining performance. Recent advancements have focused on improving these architectures for battery applications. For example, Arbaoui et al. [57] enhanced LSTM models for SoH prediction, achieving mean squared
errors of approximately 0.2 to 0.4 on high-frequency datasets. Similarly, Lee et al. [58] introduced a framework that extracts features from
time-series data or ICA to train machine learning architectures such as
LSTM and Transformer models for remaining useful life prediction. **Feature** **Engineering** **and** **Hybrid** **Approaches:** In addition, Li
et al. [59] proposed a method based on features derived from ICA,
voltage discharge curves, and capacity degradation curves to estimate
SoH, followed by an LSTM model for remaining useful life prediction.
Beyond prediction, Zou et al. [60] applied machine learning to classify
cells after production based on quality and used formation data for
lifetime prediction. **Alternative** **and** **Non-Parametric** **Methods:** An alternative approach involves constructing a reference aging surface across a threedimensional space defined by battery age _𝑡_, cumulative usage _𝑢_, and
SoH. While such surfaces are typically derived from laboratory measurements, they can also be estimated from fleet data when lab data
is unavailable. Fleet-derived surfaces capture the variability necessary
to represent real-world usage behaviors. To achieve this, RFRs can
be trained, combining multiple regression trees for high-dimensional
regression tasks [61]. Random Forests have been successfully applied
in domains such as household price prediction [62] and macroeconomic forecasting [63]. For a detailed introduction, see Breiman [61]. Alternatively, custom parameterized functions can be fitted using
standard non-linear optimization algorithms for constrained problems,
as introduced by Byrd et al. [64]. _2.4._ _Motivation_ _for_ _the_ _proposed_ _framework_ While these studies provide valuable insights, they often assume
homogeneous usage patterns or rely on laboratory data with specialized measurements, which limits their applicability to large-scale, realworld fleets. Addressing these gaps motivates the data-driven framework introduced in this paper. By systematically integrating regulatory
boundary prediction, SoH estimation, and behavioral clustering into
a modular, scalable pipeline, the proposed workflow connects operational behaviors with battery aging and regulatory compliance,
enabling the derivation of test parameters and the identification of
critical usage patterns.

**3.** **Description** **of** **the** **dataset** The dataset on which the methodology is tested later on is the
anonymized fleet data of BEVs produced by Volkswagen AG. It is
provided by the vehicle manufacturer and consists of electric vehicles
that are based on the _Modularer_ _E-Antriebs_ _Baukasten_ (MEB) vehicle architecture, which has been in production since late 2019 [65]. The fleet
itself comprises more than one million vehicles worldwide, including
various types ranging from hatchbacks like the _ID.3_ to sedans like the
_ID.7_ and minibuses/vans like the _ID._ _Buzz_ . However, the original dataset does not include all vehicles from
the fleet due to data availability constraints. After applying the preprocessing steps described in Section 5, which involve filtering out
contextual anomalies and ensuring data consistency, approximately
850,000 vehicles remain for analysis. This processed dataset will be
further referenced as  . Details on the fleet composition by vehicle type and year of production/sale can be found in the Volkswagen AG’s annual reports (Annual
report 2020: [66], 2021: [67], 2022: [68], 2023: [69]). Unfortunately, _Energy_ _and_ _AI_ _24_ _(2026)_ _100669_ **Table** **1**

In general, vehicles in the fleet have been sold to over 50 countries
worldwide, resulting in diverse usage patterns across regions. To illustrate these differences, Fig. 1 highlights operating variations
among five representative countries: China, Germany, Italy, Norway,
and the United States for the 75th-percentile of all customers within
each respective country. Notable regional variations in usage include,
for example, an average C-rate of 0 _._ 6 C in China compared to 0 _._ 3 C in
Germany. Similar disparities occur in other parameters, such as DC
charging frequency (62 % for Chinese users versus 20 % for German
users) and daily mileage (66 km∕d versus 48 km∕d). Additional information on the fleet dataset is provided by Saam
et al. [20], including vehicle type composition, customer-selected battery sizes, and country representation. That work also reports operating differences across the same five countries for the 25th- and
50th-percentiles. These regional differences in usage behavior, such as daily mileage
and charging preferences, underscore the value of vehicle-generated
data for understanding real-world operational patterns. In this work,
_usage_ _behavior_ refers to operational practices and conditions, including
charging habits, SoC ranges, and temperature exposure, among other
factors. A detailed discussion of behavioral patterns and their influence
on aging is provided in Section 4. To manage local storage constraints and enable meaningful analysis,
Volkswagen aggregates raw vehicle data into standardized matrices
during runtime. The fleet dataset  consists of _𝑁_ vehicles, each generating multiple aggregated matrices with different formats. Each matrix
typically represents either a single parameter or a pair of parameters,
allowing for efficient analysis of vehicle usage patterns. The most relevant parameters included are charge/discharge current, temperature,
and SoC. Each matrix has a fixed shape of _𝐼_ × _𝐽_ bins across all vehicles.
In this work, a single matrix type is considered across all _𝑁_ vehicles,
resulting in a three-dimensional tensor:  ∈ R _[𝐼]_ [×] _[𝐽]_ [×] _[𝑁]_

 ∈ R _[𝐼]_ [×] _[𝐽]_ [×] _[𝑁]_ where _𝐼_ and _𝐽_ denote the number of bins for the two selected parameters. This structure enables efficient fleet-wide analysis while preserving per-vehicle granularity. One example of such a matrix, and the one
used in this paper, is shown in Table 1. In this case, one parameter
(e.g., SoC) defines the columns and another (e.g., temperature) defines
the rows. These axes are divided into value ranges, and each cell
_𝐴𝑖,𝑗_ contains the retention period in days for the corresponding SoC
and temperature range. Alongside the matrix data, each protocol also
captures key metadata, most notably the vehicle’s age and total mileage
at the time of data retrieval. Data for each vehicle is retrieved manually during workshop visits,
which occur at least every 741 days in 99 % of cases, close to the recommended maximum interval between check-ups of 730 days [71]. The 4

_R._ _Saam_ _et_ _al._ _Energy_ _and_ _AI_ _24_ _(2026)_ _100669_ **Fig.** **1.** Differences in the 75th-percentile of customer usage patterns across China, Germany, Italy, Norway and the United States, based on fleet data from
Volkswagen AG. data retrieved during one visit is referred to as a _protocol_ . Due to this
manual retrieval process, no fixed sampling rate is applied, resulting
in inhomogeneous time intervals both within individual vehicles and
across the fleet. Due to the sensitivity of the fleet dataset, some steps of the methodology are evaluated using an additional, openly available battery lifetime dataset from CALCE [24]. This dataset contains accelerated cycle
life testing data for 192 different _𝐿𝑖𝐶𝑜𝑂_ 2-graphite pouch cells with a
capacity of 3 _._ 36 Ah. The cells were divided into 24 distinct groups, each
with different test parameters, and each group consists of eight newly
manufactured unique cells. Various ambient temperatures ranging from
10 °C to 60 °C were applied. Discharge C-rates varied between 0 _._ 7 C and
2 C, while constant current charging was typically performed at 1 _._ 5 C
across most of the SoC range. The charge process was terminated in
the constant voltage phase once the current dropped to either _𝐶_ ∕5 or
_𝐶_ ∕40. In 99 % of cases, the sampling interval is below 29 min. In contrast to the Volkswagen AG dataset, the CALCE dataset is
provided in a time-series format, including parameters such as test
time, applied current, charged and discharged capacity, and a cycle
counter. The dataset is split into multiple individual files spanning
across different DUTs and test cycles. Each DUT is assigned a unique
ID composed of the test group and the cell number: DUT ID ∶ test group − cell number For further details on the dataset and the experimental design,
please refer to Pecht and Osterman [24]. In the following sections, this
dataset will be referred to as  and serves as a benchmark for validating
the proposed methodology under controlled aging conditions. While
both datasets,  and , are used to evaluate the proposed methodology,
the interpretation and application of battery age _𝑡_ and cumulative usage
_𝑢_ differ depending on the dataset context. Table 2 summarizes these
differences. **Table** **2**
Overview of the differences in the usage of the battery age _𝑡_ and the cumulative
usage _𝑢_ depending on the dataset.

**Table** **2**
Overview of the differences in the usage of the battery age _𝑡_ and the cumulative
usage _𝑢_ depending on the dataset. Volkswagen AG CALCE dataset 
fleet dataset  **4.** **Influence** **of** **usage** **behavior** **on** **battery** **aging** Battery aging is strongly influenced by usage behavior, as demonstrated in various studies. For instance, von Bülow [16] provides an
overview of stressors, defined as combinations of operational conditions that induce or accelerate aging. Vermeer et al. [15] offers
a comprehensive review of aging causes, mechanisms, degradation
modes, effects, and their interdependencies. Keil et al. [14] conducted
calendar aging tests at temperatures ranging from 10 °C to 55 °C and
across different SoCs, demonstrating that high storage temperatures
significantly accelerate aging. Broussely et al. [13] contributed foundational insights into the distinction between cyclic and calendar aging
mechanisms. Schreiber et al. [18] explored the impact of different
driving profiles, such as highway versus commuter scenarios, on longterm battery health, showing that highway profiles with higher C-rates
can lead to up to four times faster degradation. Additionally, Geslin
et al. [19] highlighted increased longevity when dynamic cycling is
applied compared to constant current profiles. Fig. 2 illustrates several
usage-specific parameters and their connection to internal battery aging
phenomena. The aging causes shown in Fig. 2 affect battery degradation in
different ways. It is important to note that aging processes are also

and sizing, showing that larger cells accelerate aging. However, these
aspects are not further explored in this work, as they are not directly
influenced by customer usage behavior. Independent of chemistry and
geometry, battery aging can be broadly categorized into two types:
calendar aging, which occurs over time (e.g., when the vehicle is
parked), and cyclic aging, which results from active usage. Calendar
aging typically dominates due to long idle periods, as Nobis and Kuhnimhof [75] reported an average daily driving distance of only 40 km per
vehicle in Germany. Saam et al. [20] found that among five countries,
Chinese customers in the 75th-percentile drive the most (66 km∕d),
while German customers drive the least (48 km∕d). In contrast, cyclic
aging is heavily influenced by driving behavior. Schreiber et al. [18]
demonstrated this by comparing six distinct driving profiles, showing
that highway scenarios with higher C-rates lead to significantly faster
degradation. Additionally, Guo and Chen [76] showed that the DoD
plays a critical role in battery longevity, with higher DoDs leading to
shorter service life. Building on these observations, usage behavior emerges as a key
driver of aging variability. In real-world applications, a wide variety of
usage behaviors, or behavioral patterns, exists, each influencing battery
degradation in distinct ways. In the context of this work, behavioral
patterns refer to specific operational practices and conditions under
which a vehicle is used. These include, for example, DoD, ambient
temperature exposure, and charging habits (e.g., fast vs. slow charging).
Each of these parameters contributes to the rate and nature of battery
degradation, particularly in terms of capacity fade over time. The combination of these parameters constitutes a unique behavioral pattern.
Fig. 3 illustrates the impact of usage differences (as shown in Fig. 1) on
battery aging. It can be observed that vehicles in China exhibit slower
degradation compared to the overall fleet, whereas vehicles in Italy and
the United States experience an accelerated decline in SoH.

Given that capacity fade is a key indicator of battery aging, these
usage-specific parameters are critical in determining whether a vehicle
remains within the SoH thresholds mandated by regulatory authorities.
Accordingly, behavioral patterns can be broadly categorized into two
groups: those that are relevant for a recall and those that are not.
Patterns relevant for a recall are typically associated with accelerated
aging, potentially causing a vehicle to exceed SoH thresholds before
reaching its expected service life or mileage. The following condition outlines the scenarios in which a vehicle either complies with or

requirements across the relevant portion of the vehicle fleet. **5.** **Methodology** The motivation for identifying key usage patterns arises from observed regional differences in vehicle operation, as illustrated in Fig.
1, and their impact on aging shown in Fig. 3. Further details on these
regional differences are provided by Saam et al. [20]. Such differences
and their influence on aging highlight the need for a framework that
can isolate usage patterns contributing to battery degradation, independent of geographic or operational context. Unlike most existing studies,
a data-driven approach is adopted that does not rely on historical
load profiles. This choice reflects a different objective: using SoH
estimates to identify similar usage groups and, consequently, derive
representative load profiles. While this manuscript focuses on developing such a framework, the empirical basis for regional variability
is well established in prior work; see the sources in Section 4. The
present implementation uses comparatively simple, well-established
methods as illustrative building blocks. These are not proposed as
optimal algorithms but as exchangeable components within a modular
workflow that can be upgraded with more sophisticated techniques in
future work.

The matrices introduced in Section 3 alone cannot determine
whether the values within them are responsible for aging behavior that
complies with regulatory requirements. This limitation arises because
they do not account for the presence of faulty cells in the battery
or aging phenomena that cause capacity and power fade. Therefore,
a comparison with matrices of the same type from other vehicles is necessary to isolate vehicle-specific aging effects and identify outliers
or anomalies. This comparison is performed using the framework illustrated in
Fig. 4, which identifies usage behaviors based on available fleet data
that lead to similar battery aging. The framework consists of multiple
steps. Before identifying these usage behaviors, preliminary actions
must be taken to ensure a reliable data basis for the algorithms. These
actions include minimizing corrupted data and outliers, reducing noise,
and ensuring a homogeneous data format. These steps are represented
by _Data_ _Cleansing_ and _Feature_ _Engineering_ . For the Volkswagen AG
dataset , the following steps were performed: For the CALCE dataset , a different set of steps was required due
to its structure and characteristics. These steps are as follows: - Combining individual files per DUT/subcycles into a single file spanning the entire DUT test duration. - Converting raw data into an aggregated matrix format to establish a similar data structure compared to the Volkswagen AG dataset

given dataset, the surveys by Hodge and Austin [79] and Souiden

algorithms. Hodge and Austin [79] discusses approaches such as statistical methods, neural networks, machine learning techniques, and

anomaly detection in high-dimensional datasets and identifies current

of roughly 3500 vehicles has been identified that already surpasses at
least one regulatory boundary. This represents an extreme case within
the dataset. None of these 3500 vehicles has exceeded the eight-year
age boundary, as MEB vehicles have only been in production since late
2019 [65]. However, all of them have already surpassed the mileage
regulation. Fig. 6 illustrates the distribution of regulation boundary
intersections for this extreme subsample, showing that most vehicles
intersect the mileage boundary between 1.5 and 4 years. Due to the low sampling frequency, caused by long intervals between workshop visits, these intersections are estimated based on
the last data point below _𝑃𝑡𝑖<_ Regulation∧ _𝑢𝑖<_ Regulation and the first data
point above _𝑃𝑡𝑖_ ≥Regulation∨ _𝑢𝑖_ ≥Regulation. To reach such high mileage in
a relatively short time, these vehicles must have traveled more than
35 _,_ 000 km annually. This places them in an extreme usage category, especially considering that 95 % of the fleet travels less than
32 _,_ 000 km annually and 75 % travels less than 20 _,_ 000 km, based on the
available protocol data. It is important to note that these 3500 vehicles do not constitute a
representative sample of the entire fleet but rather highlight edge cases
with unusually high usage intensity.

It is important to note that these 3500 vehicles do not constitute a
representative sample of the entire fleet but rather highlight edge cases
with unusually high usage intensity. In contrast to the extreme subsample, Fig. 7 presents a fleet-wide
prediction of regulation boundary intersections. Here, the peak observed in the subsample shifts toward the center of the plot, corresponding to an age of eight years and a mileage of 160 _,_ 000 km. The overall fleet prediction exhibits a primary peak at approximately 112 _,_ 000 km,
highlighted in red. A secondary peak at 0 km results from protocols
generated prior to vehicle delivery, for which no subsequent data is
available. While the fleet-wide prediction in Fig. 7 suggests that most vehicles
will intersect regulatory boundaries around eight years, this estimate
is based on extrapolation and carries inherent limitations. Specifically,
the methodology assumes stable usage behavior over time and does
not account for drastic changes, such as those caused by vehicle resale
or special operating conditions (e.g., rental or company cars). For
context, as of 2024, Germany had approximately 330,000 rental or carsharing vehicles, representing only 0 _._ 67 % of all passenger vehicles [81].
Furthermore, leasing contracts in Europe typically end after three to
four years [82], and in Germany, 13 _._ 5 % of all ownership transfers involve vehicles younger than two years [82]. Such factors can introduce
deviations in the predicted intersections. These deviations are illustrated in Fig. 8, ranging from −31 % to 12 %
for 95 % of the data when comparing predicted intersections to observed
protocol points. However, when considering the entire intersection
range, deviations reduce significantly to between −11 % to 4 %. For 75 %
of the data, the relative error narrows further to −6 % to 3 _._ 5 %, and
for 50 %, to −2 % to 1 %. It is important to note that these deviations
may be slightly affected by the absence of ground truth for the exact
intersection points, primarily due to large time gaps between protocol
entries. _5.1.2._ _Application_ _to_ _the_ _CALCE_ _dataset_ The regulation boundaries defined by Euro-7 or ACCII are not
applicable to the CALCE dataset due to its fundamentally different
use case (automotive operation versus laboratory testing). Therefore,
artificial boundaries based solely on the available test data  are introduced. These boundaries do not reflect real-world requirements and are
intended exclusively for visualization and methodological verification: - Age boundary: 40 days - Cycle boundary: 400 9

employed as an alternative approach for SoH estimation. Specifically,
four architectures are evaluated: a MLP, a RNN, its predecessor LSTM,
and a GRU. These models are selected for their ability to capture nonlinear relationships and temporal dependencies in sequential battery
data. Unlike several studies discussed in Section 2, advanced feature
engineering techniques could not be applied due to the absence of highfrequency sampling and specialized measurement cycles (e.g., EIS or
ICA) in the Volkswagen AG dataset. These methods typically require
low C-rates and controlled laboratory conditions, which are unavailable
in large-scale fleet data.

Unlike several studies discussed in Section 2, advanced feature
engineering techniques could not be applied due to the absence of highfrequency sampling and specialized measurement cycles (e.g., EIS or
ICA) in the Volkswagen AG dataset. These methods typically require
low C-rates and controlled laboratory conditions, which are unavailable
in large-scale fleet data. In this study, a 80/20 train-validation split was applied, consistent
with prior works [83,84]. To minimize bias from a single partition, the
training data was randomly shuffled at each epoch, ensuring diverse
sample exposure during optimization. This strategy provides a practical
balance between computational efficiency and reliable generalization
assessment. The MLP model uses the current feature vector _𝑟_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ ) and
its corresponding SoH( _𝑟_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ )) to predict the next SoH given the subsequent _𝑟_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ ). In contrast, the recurrent architectures, RNN, LSTM, and
GRU, leverage the previous nine feature vectors and their associated
SoH( _𝑟_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ )) values to predict the next SoH using the tenth _𝑟_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ ). For
vehicles or DUTs with fewer than ten samples, missing entries are zeropadded to ensure that all input sequences have a consistent length. The
input–output structure is illustrated in Fig. 11. To identify the most suitable architecture, a hyperparameter search
is conducted. Rather than performing an exhaustive search, a pragmatic
approach is adopted by executing 10 runs per model for each of the two
datasets  and . This strategy balances computational efficiency with
sufficient exploration of the hyperparameter space. Table 4 summarizes the best-performing hyperparameter configurations identified during the search for datasets  and . The search
focused only on a subset of a few hyperparameters, as the primary
objective was to validate the workflow rather than achieve globally
optimal models. _5.2.4._ _Comparison_ _of_ _state_ _of_ _health_ _estimation_ _methods_ Tables 5 and 6 summarize the error distribution of nine SoH estimation methods across two datasets: the fleet dataset  and the
CALCE dataset . The results reveal substantial performance differences
between classical regression-based approaches and machine learning
models, as well as across datasets. Percentiles are reported instead of
mean errors to provide a robust measure of performance across the
distribution and reduce sensitivity to outliers.

Tables 5 and 6 summarize the error distribution of nine SoH estimation methods across two datasets: the fleet dataset  and the
CALCE dataset . The results reveal substantial performance differences
between classical regression-based approaches and machine learning
models, as well as across datasets. Percentiles are reported instead of
mean errors to provide a robust measure of performance across the

aging behavior in  . The best performance in  is achieved by _𝑔_ 3 for
the 50th and 75th percentiles, while the MLP slightly outperforms _𝑔_ 3
at the 95th percentile. Second-best overall in  is the MLP, followed
by the two RFRs, _𝑓_ 1 (constant offset) and _𝑓_ 2 (increasing offset). Next
comes _𝑔_ 2 with its linear fit. The recurrent models (RNN, LSTM, GRU)
also outperform _𝑔_ 1, but still lag behind the other methods. In contrast, performance rankings shift for . The top four models
are machine learning-based, followed by _𝑔_ 3. Afterward, RFR _𝑓_ 2 outperforms _𝑓_ 1 by more than 2 %, placing _𝑓_ 1 second to last. Similarly,
_𝑔_ 2 surpasses _𝑓_ 1 by over 1 _._ 6 %. The superior performance of machine
learning models on  is likely due to its higher sampling frequency,
which provides a larger quantity of training samples. This particularly
benefits recurrent networks, as the fleet dataset often lacks sufficient
consecutive samples (e.g., fewer than nine observations to predict the
tenth). Based on these results, _𝑔_ 3( _𝑡, 𝑢_ ) is selected for subsequent analyses
due to its superior performance on the fleet dataset  . However, this advantage comes at a cost: the computation of _𝑔_ 3 is time-intensive because

promising alternative. They can capture non-linear relationships, account for variability in mileage patterns, and adapt to evolving behaviors, making them better suited for predicting intersections under
diverse and dynamic conditions. However, these models require additional contextual information, such as indicators for resale events,

and adjust for abrupt shifts in behavior. Without such features, even

In addition, the sampling rate of available data plays a critical
role in prediction accuracy. Higher sampling frequencies enable models
to capture short-term fluctuations and emerging trends, improving
the precision of intersection forecasts. Conversely, low sampling rates
can obscure these dynamics, leading to delayed detection of critical
changes and reduced reliability in long-term predictions. Enhancing
data acquisition strategies, for example through _Over_ _The_ _Air_ (OTA)based solutions, could therefore significantly strengthen the predictive
capability of both statistical and machine learning approaches. _6.2._ _Limitations_ _in_ _estimating_ _the_ _state_ _of_ _health_ The influence of low sampling rates on SoH estimation is clearly
visible in the Volkswagen AG fleet dataset  . Compared to the CALCE
dataset , which provides measurements at a higher sampling frequency, the performance differences between estimation methods, particularly for recurrent networks, can reach several percentage points.
This highlights that the framework benefits significantly from higher
sampling rates in fleet operations, for example by leveraging OTA
solutions to retrieve data automatically on a day-to-day basis. Another aspect concerns the handling of knee points in the degradation curve. These abrupt changes in aging behavior, often occurring
near the end of life, are not yet explicitly modeled in the current
approach. Addressing knee points in future work could improve predictions of remaining useful life and ensure compliance with regulatory
boundaries, particularly for batteries approaching critical thresholds. Additionally, during training of the models (RFR, MLP, RNN, LSTM,
GRU) only a 80/20 train-validation split has been applied. To further
reduce bias from a single partitioning and enhance robustness, incorporating K-fold cross validation would be beneficial. While this approach
increases computational requirements for large datasets, it represents a
promising avenue for improving model reliability as resources allow. Finally, the full potential of machine learning models is currently

highlights potential improvements for future work. _6.1._ _Limitations_ _in_ _predicting_ _the_ _intersection_ _with_ _regulation_ _boundaries_ Current statistical methods for predicting intersections with regulatory boundaries rely on simplified assumptions, such as constant daily
mileage. In practice, this assumption rarely holds: daily mileage can
vary due to seasonal changes, holidays, or shifts in commuting patterns.
Furthermore, abrupt changes caused by vehicle resale or ownership
transfer introduce discontinuities that these models cannot capture. Another limitation is sensitivity to outliers, such as occasional longdistance trips or extended periods of inactivity, which can distort
predictions. 15

charging behavior of the DUTs, captures only one dimension of usage
and does not fully explain why the groups intersect at different battery
ages _𝑡_ and cumulative usages _𝑢_ . Nevertheless, a clear connection between usage patterns and aging
behavior is evident. Differences in charging behavior lead to distinct aging outcomes: _𝐺_ 2 and _𝐺_ 3 exhibit less aging compared to _𝐺_ 1, which
has an average SoH of 78 %, whereas _𝐺_ 3 and _𝐺_ 2 reach 92 % and
97 %, respectively. This correlates with C-rate differences: _𝐺_ 1 has the
highest C-rate, followed by _𝐺_ 3 and _𝐺_ 2, consistent with the well-known
phenomenon that higher C-rates accelerate aging.

However, charging behavior alone does not fully explain variations in regulatory boundary intersections or aging differences. Other
influential factors include discharge rate, which varies significantly
among DUTs: some operate at 0 _._ 7 C, while others reach 2 C. Additional variations include cycling temperature and rest time. For example, the blue cluster with min( _𝑧_ ( _𝑡𝑄, 𝑢𝑄_ ) _𝑚_ ) and the green cluster with
max( _𝑧_ ( _𝑡𝑄, 𝑢𝑄_ ) _𝑚_ ) exhibit cycling temperatures around 10 °C, whereas
the red cluster with min(| _𝑧_ ( _𝑡, 𝑢_ ) _𝑚_ |) operates at approximately 25 °C.
Rest time further influences aging and the point of intersection with
regulatory boundaries. 16

_R._ _Saam_ _et_ _al._ While the current approach uses single-view clustering based solely
on one usage behavior, such as charging behavior, this representation
is inherently limited. It risks overlooking other influential dimensions,
including discharge patterns, temperature, and rest periods, which can
lead to biased group formation and incomplete insights into aging
mechanisms. Consequently, an improved approach may be required
depending on the use case, one that considers multiple dimensions of
usage behavior. A promising solution is an extension of the current
framework by incorporating a multi-view clustering approach, where
each view represents a distinct aspect of usage. For instance, one view
could capture charging behavior at different C-rates, another could
represent discharge C-rates, and a third could include rest time at
specific temperatures and SoC intervals. Such a framework enables a
more comprehensive distinction between usage patterns and a more
accurate assessment of their influence on aging. For further details on
multi-view clustering, see Chao et al. [91], who illustrates the concept
using image features, and Moujahid and Dornaika [92], who provides
an overview of recent surveys and techniques. _6.4._ _Framework_ _flexibility_ _and_ _future_ _extensions_ An important strength of the proposed framework is its modular
design. Each step can be replaced by improved methods as long as
the input and output interfaces remain consistent. For example, more
advanced machine learning models could substitute the current regression approach for predicting intersections with regulatory boundaries,
or alternative clustering algorithms could replace K-Means without
affecting subsequent steps. This flexibility ensures that the framework
can evolve with future advancements in predictive modeling and data
analysis while maintaining overall compatibility. To guide methodological extensions, the framework provides clear
modular interfaces. Future work could incorporate survival analysis
or deep learning models for intersection prediction, integrate kneepoint detection for improved SoH estimation, or adopt multi-view
clustering to capture complex behavioral patterns. These enhancements
would enable a more accurate and comprehensive assessment of aging
influences while preserving the overall workflow structure. **7.** **Summary** **and** **outlook**

**7.** **Summary** **and** **outlook** This paper demonstrated clear usage behavioral differences across
five countries (China, Germany, Italy, Norway, and the United States),
emphasizing the need for a methodology that identifies key usage
behaviors for regulatory compliance testing. A data-driven framework
was introduced to predict battery age _𝑡_ and cumulative usage _𝑢_ at
intersections with regulatory boundaries, estimate SoH at these points,
and cluster vehicles into representative aging groups. Validation on
the Volkswagen AG fleet and _Center_ _for_ _Advanced_ _Life_ _Cycle_ _Engi-_
_neering_ (CALCE) datasets achieved clustering scores of _Homogeneity_
0.9157 and _Completeness_ 0.9509. Unlike software frameworks providing
implemented modular components, this work conceptually integrates
established techniques, regulatory boundary prediction, SoH estimation, and behavioral clustering, into a cohesive analytical pipeline. This
integration enables comprehensive analysis linking battery aging to
usage behavior and regulatory compliance, facilitating interpretability
and adaptability to evolving operational and regulatory contexts. While the methodology shows strong potential, limitations such as
reliance on single-view clustering and sensitivity to sampling frequency
remain. Future work should incorporate multi-view clustering to capture multiple dimensions of usage behavior (e.g., charging, discharging,
rest time or temperature), knee-point detection for improved lifetime
prediction, and advanced machine learning models for intersection
estimation. The modular design of the framework allows these enhancements to be integrated as drop-in replacements without altering
the overall structure. Thus, the main contribution lies in the integrative framework and its validation on large-scale fleet and laboratory _Energy_ _and_ _AI_ _24_ _(2026)_ _100669_ **Table** **8**

capabilities, and power grid planning. Its adaptable nature makes it
suitable for other domains where fleet data and lifetime-relevant _Key_

accounted for during feature engineering. Overall, this work presents
a systematic, scalable approach to link real-world vehicle usage with
battery aging dynamics, providing actionable insights for industry and
research in the evolving landscape of electric mobility regulations. **CRediT** **authorship** **contribution** **statement** **Robin** **Saam:** Writing  - original draft, Visualization, Software,
